title: Inkwell, ca. 1890–1900
markings: On unglazed underside; signature (in script) "Dalpayrat" and illegible marks -9?5 over ?F "ox."
provenance: 2013, Given to Cooper-Hewitt by owner Harry C. Sigman
description: Of square section with canted corners, the mottled green-red glazed stoneware set on a gilt-bronze base, with gilt-bronze scrolling overlay rising to a mount at the lip wth hinged lid.
justification: Characteristic of&nbsp;good&nbsp;French Art Nouveau&nbsp;design, this inkwell is an example of&nbsp;the&nbsp;stylistic unity&nbsp;created by&nbsp;co-ordinating&nbsp;artistic style in different materials used together,&nbsp;including&nbsp;instances of media&nbsp;by different designers.&nbsp;Dalpayrat's ceramics were often as fluid as the metalwork mounts that adorn this inkwell. In this case, he chose a fairly traditional form in order to feature his other interest---free-flowing and innovative glazes that flow around on the stoneware as if&nbsp;they were enamel&nbsp;on metal. Visible in the glazes is the red that came to be known as Dalpayrat red,&nbsp;due to his mastery of the color.&nbsp;Some of Dalpayrat's work for Samuel Bing was embellished with&nbsp;bronze mounts executed by Edouard Colonna. &nbsp;It is possible that the mounts on this inkwell were also by Colonna.

tombstone.epitaph: Inkwell, ca. 1890–1900. Glazed stoneware, cast gilt bronze. Gift of Harry C. Sigman. 2013-21-1.
